--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Hi Derek, I wrote my robot control code off of
> previously
> existing Khepera simulator software.  So the core of
> the
> code is from that, although it's been much expanded
> and
> changed.  

Ah, okay...cool.

> The one concern is that some simulators are not
> built for
> training, which means that they may not let you turn
> off
> the graphics or run in "fast forward" mode.  

TeamBots does have a "graphics-off" mode, so it does
look like a good start.  I also believe that the
SoccerBots extension allows you to parameterize the
length of a time-step and also allows the speeding up
of graphical animation.

> To answer your second question, if NEAT is trained
> on a
> realistic simulation of a real physical robot (e.g.
> Khepera)
> then the results should be transferable.  In
> practice, the
> transfer will not be a perfect and a few extra
> generations
> of refinement evolution in the real world may be
> necessary.

That makes sense.  Does porting the evolved ANNs to
hardware appeal to you at all? 

I know those robots can be a bit pricey, at least from
just poking around on the net.

> I think trying your ANJI NEAT (hmm...how to say it?)
> with
> robot simulators would be great.  NEAT is known to
> be good
> in that kind of domain.

Well, we're hoping to collect a nice, large set of
domains/fitness functions in the SourceForge
repository for the project.  It'd be great to see
anyone here who's interested in contributing.  

Derek
